Done.
Thank you Miora, that's really good, I'll try to use this pattern in future.

timeline.bodyText: You should use leg.hasPhaseTapChanger() that is more human readable.
timeline.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText: The hasPhaseTapChanger() is not available for Leg. Theses methods are in TapChangerParent interface. Would you like us to modify iidm Leg - add hasPhaseTapChanger() ? or make the method in TapChangerParent available for Leg?
replies.author: kaltakovae
kaltakovae

replies.bodyText: I don't think it is a good idea to make this evolution in this PR... Keep the code here as it is for now, I am opening an issue to add convenient methods such as hasPhaseTapChanger() on APIs.
replies.author: miovd
miovd
kaltakovae

timeline.bodyText: Same improvement using leg.hasRatioTapChanger()
timeline.author: mathbagu

timeline.bodyText: It could be a good idea to add this convenient feature to the network.
timeline.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText: I will write an issue related to that
replies.author: miovd

timeline.bodyText: Not sure this is OK: If a line is connected on side 1 but disconnected on side 2, I'm not sure the IN_SERVICE should be true.
timeline.author: mathbagu

replies.bodyText: I agree with @mathbagu, not sure what is put in the property bag, it always is the connectivity status of the last terminal, right? Is it what we want?
replies.author: miovd

replies.bodyText:
The definition for inService attribute for a ConductingEquipment states that it is: The in service status as a result of topology processing.
For me: if a conducting equipment with multiple terminals has at least one terminal connected, it should be considered in-service. At least it makes sense from a modeling point of view, and its impact in the network could be calculated.
replies.author: zamarrenolm

replies.bodyText: In fact Miora seems to say that we only keep the status of the last terminal we have checked. So what is the good solution to put inService when at least one terminal is connected ?
replies.author: annetill

replies.bodyText: We will change it for "any" terminal, instead of "last"
replies.author: kaltakovae

timeline.bodyText: Are you sure this check is needed: in which case the terminal is null?
timeline.author: mathbagu

timeline.bodyText: This test is not necessary, the for-each at line 323 seems sufficient. If it's empty the `byTopologicalIslandId will be empty, and the for-each loop at line 336 won't loop.
timeline.author: mathbagu

timeline.bodyText: Can be static

replies.bodyText: I don't think so because it uses the cgmes attribute.

timeline.bodyText: Does it work from a node/breaker CGMES file? In this case, topological nodes ID are not kept, are they?
timeline.author: MioRtia

replies.bodyText: Correct, NodeBreaker view require further investigation to map correctly Topological Nodes. It will be done with the next iteration.
replies.author: kaltakovae

timeline.bodyText: Why are you wrapping it in unmodifiableList? It should work with Arrays.asList(...).forEach(...)
timeline.author: MioRtia

replies.bodyText: you're right, we don't keep the object here, the list is already immutable. I'll clean out the 'unmodifiable'
replies.author: kaltakovae

timeline.bodyText: Does the case c.getId() == null happen? If not, it may not be necessary to test it.
timeline.author: MioRtia

timeline.bodyText: Again, I don't think this case can happen (in IIDM, when a connectable is created, at least one terminal is created with it).
timeline.author: MioRtia

timeline.bodyText: can be static
timeline.author: MioRtia

replies.bodyText: Done. Eventually, we removed the method at all, as we realized it could be done using existing methods PropertyBags.pluckLocals()

timeline.bodyText:
@mathbagu We discussed it but I don't really like that getConnectables() does not ensure that the elements are distinct
@kaltakovae Do you have a case in which the same Connectable is met several times? In any case, I think you should drop this check, I will make another PR to ensure the list/stream is distinct. Besides, you can use the stream API here.
timeline.author: MioRtia

replies.bodyText:
Currently we observe multiple duplicates, e.g. for each Line or Transformer getConnectables() duplicates results. We've tested with MicroGrid and HOPS test cases.
But, even if getConnectables() results in distincts, we still need the check for duplicates here:
Without this check any Connectables which are in different VoltageLevels (e.g Transformers) will be duplicated or triplicated.
replies.author: kaltakovae
miovd

replies.bodyText:
About finding duplicates:
There is no getConnectables at Network level, so to obtain all connectables of the network we must iterate first over the voltage levels, then its connectables.
This means that we have to account for potential duplicates: lines and 2w transformers will be found twice, once for every end, and 3w transformers will appear three times during the iteration.
So, unless we have a getConnectables at Network level, we have to take into account for potential duplicates.
An alternative could be to iterate over specific types of equipment (getLines, getTransformers, getGenerators, getLoads, ...) but that would mean to have a long list of method calls, and leave the risk of omitting new types when they are added to the Network (in the future). I mean, leaving a long list of specific dependencies when a generic treatment over all kind of equipment can be done.
replies.author: zamarrenolm

replies.bodyText: @MioRtia  Thank you Miora, this mathes perfectly to what we wanted. I've done the change.
replies.author: kaltakovae

timeline.message:
